content.body: emilio: so :active/:hover use the flat tree, but :has() uses the node tree? Is using the flat tree for selector matching not really expensive?
content.formatted_body: emilio: so :active/:hover use the flat tree, but :has() uses the node tree? Is using the flat tree for selector matching not really expensive?

content.body:
> <@annevk:mozilla.org> emilio: so :active/:hover use the flat tree, but :has() uses the node tree? Is using the flat tree for selector matching not really expensive?

That is right. :has() uses the node tree like all other selector combinators, why would it use the flat tree?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:mozilla.org
emilio: so :active/:hover use the flat tree, but :has() uses the node tree? Is using the flat tree for selector matching not really expensive?
That is right. :has() uses the node tree like all other selector combinators, why would it use the flat tree?

content.body: Not that it would be impossible to do but it'd be weird
emilio: yeah never mind, I guess it all makes sense. And :has can't really use the flat tree as that'd break encapsulation, I think.
content.formatted_body: emilio: yeah never mind, I guess it all makes sense. And :has can't really use the flat tree as that'd break encapsulation, I think.

content.body: Thinking of trying to tackle https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/849 again, or at least make progress ... is there any easy way to know what element names the HTML parser accepts? Or do I have to walk through various parser states?
I guess looking at https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#tag-open-state + tag name state is not too bad...
can someone who understands how event dispatch is specified comment on https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=234730? because I've utterly confused myself now.
